skill.name: reasoning-dialectical
skill.description: Synthesize competing positions through structured thesis-antithesis-synthesis process. Use when stakeholders disagree, trade-offs exist, or multiple valid perspectives need integration. Produces integrated positions with acknowledged trade-offs.

skill.author: BellaBe

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation file containing only markdown text describing a dialectical reasoning methodology. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, no environment variable reads. Contains only templates, examples, and guidance for structured argumentation.

content.user_title: Synthesize opposing viewpoints with dialectical reasoning
content.value_statement: Teams struggle when stakeholders hold conflicting positions. This skill structures productive disagreement using thesis-antithesis-synthesis to find integrated solutions that acknowledge trade-offs.
actual_capabilities: Articulate competing positions at maximum strength using steel-man argumentation
Identify underlying stakeholder concerns beyond stated positions
Generate integrated synthesis through five resolution approaches
Document explicit trade-offs with mitigation strategies
Create actionable implementation plans with success metrics
Facilitate stakeholder acknowledgment of synthesis outcomes
limitations: Does not execute code or access external systems
Requires users to provide evidence and stakeholder perspectives
Does not make decisions - only structures the reasoning process
Quality of output depends on input from all stakeholders

use_cases.title: Resolve feature prioritization conflicts
use_cases.description: Balance engineering debt reduction requests with sales feature demands through structured synthesis.

use_cases.title: Evaluate strategic trade-offs
use_cases.description: Compare competing strategic initiatives by surfacing underlying concerns and finding integrative paths forward.

use_cases.title: Align competing team priorities
use_cases.description: Mediate between team proposals by ensuring each position is fairly represented and synthesized.

prompt_templates.title: Basic synthesis request
prompt_templates.prompt: Use dialectical reasoning to synthesize these positions: [Position A details] versus [Position B details]. Provide thesis, antithesis, and synthesis with trade-offs.

prompt_templates.title: Stakeholder alignment
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply dialectical reasoning to align these stakeholders: [Stakeholder 1 position and concerns] versus [Stakeholder 2 position and concerns]. Include stakeholder acknowledgment protocol.

prompt_templates.title: Strategic trade-off analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Use dialectical reasoning to analyze this strategic decision: [Option A with evidence] versus [Option B with evidence]. Generate synthesis with explicit trade-offs and implementation actions.

prompt_templates.title: Complex multi-party resolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Synthesize these multiple positions using dialectical reasoning: [Position 1], [Position 2], [Position 3]. Identify the core tensions, generate integration approaches, and document all trade-offs.

output_examples.input: Use dialectical reasoning to resolve: Engineering wants 6 months to rebuild the platform. Sales needs new features for Q2 deals worth $2M in pipeline.
output: THESIS (Engineering): Technical debt is blocking velocity. Rebuild now or pay 10x later. Evidence: 300% YoY deploy time increase, 40% of sprint on workarounds.
ANTITHESIS (Sales): $2M pipeline depends on Q2 features. Delay equals lost deals. Evidence: 5 enterprise deals waiting, competitor launching in March.
SYNTHESIS: Strangler fig pattern - rebuild incrementally while delivering high-priority features.
TRADE-OFFS: Rebuild takes 9 months (Engineering accepts), only top 3 features in Q2 (Sales accepts prioritization).
IMPLEMENTATION: Week 1 joint prioritization, Q2 deliver on new modules, Q3-Q4 complete rebuild.

best_practices: Steel-man each position before critiquing - represent opposing views at their strongest
Surface underlying concerns, not just stated positions - stakeholders often defend symptoms not causes
Require explicit stakeholder acknowledgment of trade-offs before considering synthesis complete
anti_patterns: Straw-manning opposing positions by attacking weakest arguments instead of strongest
Producing compromise instead of true synthesis - splitting differences rather than transcending the dichotomy
Skipping trade-off documentation - synthesis without acknowledged costs lacks stakeholder buy-in

faq.question: What platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. It is a prompt-based reasoning framework that guides structured argumentation.

faq.question: What is the difference between synthesis and compromise?
faq.answer: Compromise splits the difference and both sides lose something. True synthesis finds a higher-order resolution where core concerns are addressed at a deeper level.

faq.question: How many positions can this skill handle?
faq.answer: The core framework handles two positions (thesis and antithesis). For three or more, identify the primary tension first, then iterate or use segmentation approaches.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: This is a prompt-based skill with no code execution or network access. Your data remains local to your AI session and is not transmitted externally.

faq.question: Why is my synthesis too vague?
faq.answer: Common causes include skipping stakeholder concerns, failing to force concrete resource allocation, or not forcing a choice between resolution approaches. Add implementation actions and metrics.

faq.question: When should I use this over causal reasoning?
faq.answer: Use dialectical when multiple valid perspectives exist with genuine tension. Use causal when you have a clear cause-effect chain to analyze or operational process to execute.
